description: From New Latin intrōversio, from intrōvertere (“to turn within”), from Classical Latin intro- (“within”) and vertere (“to turn”). Equivalent to introvert +‎ -sion.

entries.meaning: The action of turning one's thoughts upon internal or spiritual matters.
(psychology) A personality orientation towards the self and mental abstraction; behavior expressing such orientation.
examples: ...so that when in later life there occurs an introversion (in the sense of Jung), it consists of a harking back to regressive, reminiscent, infantile material.

entries.meaning: (poetry and literature) Arrangement of two similar words, lines, etc. to form the middle part of a structure.
examples: Such introversion is merely a matter of form.
